page.title: 01SUMMARY OF BEWDLEY
page.content: {Bewdley}is a small Georgian town (pop.9500) situated on the River Severn and set in a valley of tree covered hills and farmland. Its name originates from{"Beau Lieu"}Beautiful Place. The graceful bridge which leads into the main street was built by {Thomas Telford}in 1798. Much of the West Midlands holiday traffic passes over the bridge, for Bewdley is still the{gateway to Wales.}The river is very popular with fishermen because of the good fishing and unspoilt scenery. One of Bewdley's most popular attractions is the{Severn Valley {Railway.}Steam trains run from Kidderminster to Bridgenorth. On the outskirts of the town is the{West {Midland Safari and Leisure Park,}built in 1972 by Chipperfield's. Bewdley is on the outskirt's of the{Wyre Forest abundant in wild life and oak trees.
